[Story]: The pungent odor of the sea hit Julwei first as she snapped awake. The familiar mix of old fish and gull burned her nostrils. The throbbing pain in her skull came next. Her back and shoulders burned with pain but, judging from the chill that worked down her back, nothing important was broken.


Julwei pushed herself to her feet. Wood and cloth and silver spicefish littered the dented cooling plate around her. The familiar buzz of a nearby arc core — the power source for the plate, of course — ran along her arms. She spared a glance to the man whose stall she ruined.

"Sorry."

The islander crossed his arms and narrowed his grey eyes in response.

"Fair enough." Julwei shrugged. "You see a lizard? Green scales, tall, strong."

He pointed through a hole in the yellow canopy, a hole, she was sure, recently added when Julwei fell from the cliff above. She scanned the cliff. No sign of the lizardfolk who threw her down.

"You sure he didn't follow me down?"

The man offered no response.

"You know where he went?"

Still nothing.

"Alright."

Pulling her black hair out of her face, Julwei nodded a farewell. She thought, for a moment, that the vendor may try to stop her. She had destroyed his shop, technically. He would be justified. But he only grumbled at her as she passed. Perhaps he saw some kinship in her brown eyes. He recognized her as one of his own. If not from this town — this island — another nearby.

Or perhaps he feared the gun hanging from her hip.

Raising a hand to block the sun, she scanned the town. Osprey was a small port, compared to those that dotted the coast of the kingdom, but not empty. It sat several days off the fastest trade routes, protected from intruders by storms, coral reefs, and sandbanks. Only small ships could safely navigate to the harbor, and most preferred to row in. Yet enough managed to make the journey to turn the island into one of the few trading hubs outside kingdom control. Unofficially, the kingdom deemed Osprey a lost cause and left it to pirates, rebels, and other lowlifes.

Officially, it didn't exist.

The cliffs shielded half of Osprey from the vengeful sun and colorful tarps made of flora cloth protected the rest. They were strung together between leaning multi-storey wooden structures and poles painted in pastels. The port was mostly cobbled together from the wood of half sunk ships. Only a faint suggestion of the island's original architecture remained.

Julwei watched the crowd as she made her way to the coast. Islanders, kingdom escapees, and even the occasional mekanica filled the port, but her bounty was nowhere in sight. Under different circumstances, she would be impressed how a creature with scales and a tail could disappear in a place smaller than a kingdom galleon. Even in the islands, lizardfolk were uncommon. The few she did see didn't match his height or coloring.

Her body ached with every step, a constant painful reminder of who she was hunting. Nothing compared to the pulsing in her head. At the moment, Julwei wanted nothing more than a warm bath and healing salve, but she couldn't wait. She spent a month tracking the lizardfolk to Osprey. Allowing him to escape wasn't an option.

If she was lucky, he slipped back into the jungle and fell prey to the island. If she was unlucky, he retreated and set another trap.

Either way, she still needed proof.

The beach had no shade and the sun burned Julwei's skin as she stepped into the sea. Everything on the islands was warmer. Even the water felt pleasant against her skin, except for the salt in her wounds, unlike the cold waves in the mainland. Were it not for the bounty or her debts, she might not return to the kingdom.

Even with the debts, she was tempted to stay.

Julwei knelt in the water for a moment, collecting herself. The waves pushed against her with an easy, lazy rhythm. The backwash carved grooves under her knees and boots. Salt stung the cuts she didn't even know she had. A curious scuttler inched dangerously close, snapping its pincers as a threat, but even the mere act of flicking it away seemed like too much work. Her next encounter with the lizardfolk would require a more careful approach. He was too strong to risk a direct fight, especially without taking time to recover and treat her injuries. Time she couldn't afford.

Closing her eyes, Julwei focused her mind on the bounty, calling forth an image of the lizardfolk. It was easier now that she had seen his face in person. The drawing from the bounty office didn't show his scales were green or the way the split in his lip widened when he snarled. His teeth weren't as sharp or long and a few were missing, no doubt knocked loose in a bar fight after he defected. Lizardfolk wore age differently than humans, but he looked older. Not significantly, but whoever described him remembered someone young.

The drawings showed his eyes dark and full of malice. The artist depicted him as the villain the kingdom proclaimed.

His eyes were yellow and afraid.

Julwei pictured the lizard as he was before he threw her from the cliff. Afraid but violent. Easily tossing her with one arm, the other tight on his satchel, roaring in fury. She pictured every scar, every tooth, each of the tiny spurs on his jaw and scalp, and held that image in her mind as she submerged herself.

Then she took a breath.

Her lungs screamed as she swallowed the salty water. Her body forgot the pain in her head and on her limbs. All she could feel was fire in her chest. Every sane part of her body urged her to surface, but Julwei focused her thoughts only on the lizardfolk. She pushed herself deeper into the sea, even as the darkness creeped into the corners of her mind, teasing her with death.

Some called it magic. Others sorcery, the ether, witchcraft, the cold, and many other words for the space between life and death. Few could reach it and many that could passed too far into death. The ether was power. Uncontrollable without luck or training, but power on the same. By the laws of the kingdom, witchcraft was outlawed. The problem often took care of itself but, when deemed necessary, the kingdom punished witches with ruthless efficiency.

There were exceptions. Hushed whispers spread in dark corners of the kingdom. Rumors of strange powers used by the kingdom's own enforcers — inquisitors, a dying breed of an ancient order. Rumors spread too of wealthy officials and particularly lucky gamblers, but neither seemed worthy of an inquisitor's time. The kingdom overlooked Julwei for reasons she didn't understand and didn't question. She felt the familiar chill from enough of her contracts to know the kingdom's blind eye was a privilege, not a right.

They would come for her someday. She only hoped to die before then.

As the last of her strength waned away, the world came into a new focus. Shadows shifted into smoky images painted in muted colors that turned to junglewood and stone. The smell of earth and ash filled her nose. The sounds of birds and panthers and other beasts echoed around her. Her vision sharpened and her eyes focused on a broken pyramid deep within the island.

Her bounty hadn't fled.

Julwei broke the surface, gasping for fair, and flailed wildly until the water was shallow enough for to pull herself away. Every breath stung. Between each, she purged the water from her lungs. But she could breathe. She was alive. Most importantly, the shortcut worked. She found her bounty.

By the time the sun dipped beyond the horizon — its last golden rays painting the sky in shades of orange — Julwei was deep in the jungle. Her head and lungs hadn't forgiven her yet, but impatience won out. She limped along the narrow trail, following the path now seared in her memory. The ether gave her a vague idea of her destination through her bounty's eyes, but the hike wasn't easy and the little aches began to weigh on her. She ignored the concerning noises coming from the canopy, always a creature just out of sight, though she kept her hand on her pistol as a precaution. She couldn't stop until she found shelter.

Fortunately, that had been done for her.

The lizardfolk had found a temple hidden within the island and established a camp. She had a hazy image of the ancient stone and overgrown roots in her mind, but she recognized the patterns carved on the walls. Or her bounty did, at least. She had never seen one before, though stories of similar temples spread throughout the kingdom. Some claimed that a great civilization once conquered the world, stretching beyond even the kingdom's current borders. None could explain how such a great nation could collapse and leave behind nothing but old stone.

As far as Julwei was concerned, the stepped pyramids of the islands had nothing to do with the ruins in the kingdom or the one found in the colonies. Supposed connections were nothing but delusions by novelists.

Yet she felt her pain give way to excitement. She heard stories of great explorers as a child, of dashing adventurers who retrieved relics from the clutches of vile monsters. They ventured deep into the ruins for mysterious artifacts steeped in power. Others told stories of the spirits that still haunted the temples, guarding their homes from intruders, luring them into traps or remnants of magic.

Foolish treasure hunters claimed they stole artifacts from under the nose of kingdom forces. They could rarely make such claims twice.

The kingdom encouraged rumors. They greatly appreciated the relics and exploration done by treasure hunters, officially sanctioned or not. The reward for a genuine piece of history exceeded any bounty tenfold. To keep things civil, the punishment for any forgery was severe, often death. The king's archivists were not easily fooled.

Not that Julwei needed to worry. Osprey's temple obviously remained undiscovered thus far, otherwise the kingdom's fleet would have already claimed it. No island beast or coral reef was so dangerous a thousand soldiers couldn't best it.

They might even reward her for its discovery.

The only obstacle was one lizard. The bounty would be hers. The relics would be hers to sell. And Julwei could find a warm beach to stay.

Assuming he didn't kill her.

Dusk turned to night by the time Julwei found the temple. The pyramid peaked above the canopy, a beacon between the twin Dar moons. She felt the air shift as she drew closer. A chill crept under her skin and pulled her closer to the ether. Briefly, Julwei debated her stance on temple ghosts. She found it easier to dismiss them as stories before she felt the cold.

Julwei knew there had been a time when the temple sat over nature, a triumph of its creators, but it was hard to see anything other than a ruin. Much of the original structure lost its centuries-long battle with the surrounding jungle. Only the skeleton remained. Moss and vines covered the structure's stony base. A large tree rose from what had once been a courtyard, surrounded now by rubble. Its large thick roots twisted through the gaps in the stone floor. One entrance collapsed into a pile of rock and wood. Another was blocked by overgrown vines and roots.

The jungle claimed this land. As it always would.

Checking for traps, Julwei circled the temple. She lacked the enhanced eyesight of her prey, but years of close calls taught her what to look for: a glint of light, a clearing too clean, or a silhouette out of place. She found none of these. She did, however, find her bounty's camp in the courtyard. Chests served as tables for tools, books, and buckets of colorful liquid. He built a lean-to against a decayed all, the roof made of the same floracloth of Osprey's town. A fire pit, dug into the temple itself, was full of ash, but nor embers. For a moment, Julwei thought her witchcraft might have failed her again — there was no sign the bounty here — but she felt the ether pull her inside.

Julwei pulled her pistol from its holster and approached the only unbarred entrance to the temple's interior. She stepped lightly on the stone. Her heart thundered in her chest as the memory of her last encounter with the lizardfolk forced its way to the front of her mind. She would be lucky to survive another fight.

She considered if her target would still be alive. The jungle hadn't killed either of them yet, but the temple might. She could wait the night outside and leave her bounty to the ghosts. If there was still a body, she would claim it in the morning, under the safety of the sun.

She waited for another breath, but no ghost showed itself.

The hairs on her arm stood as she crept down the passage. Moss clung to her as she brushed past and, no matter how hard she tried to brush it away, it stuck. The cold turned her veins to ice. The rhythmic tap of metal on stone echoed through the hall, growing louder as she drew closer.

Eventually, the narrow hallway opened to a larger rectangle room. More darkened paths led to dead ends on three of the chamber's four sides, blocked at their ends by nature's power. Two mighty stone pillars supported what remained of the roof. Vines dangled from a hole.

Jungle growth covered half of the fourth wall. On the other half was a mural of a man under the waning moon, behind him a pyramid much like the temple she stood in. While the man was only carved into the wall, the pyramid was lined with white and gold. Dar Eon was painted in her lunar blues, her shadows stretching beyond the confines of the wall. On the other side, Julwei could see the beginnings of a mirrored scene, no doubt with the rising twin. Between the murals, a large stone door sat a few steps above the floor.

Her bounty focused on the wall, oblivious to her as she approached. Tapping at the wall with a hammer and chisel, he carved along the ancient grooves, clearing them of moss and age. Scars crossed in patterns on his shoulders and back. His muscles rippled beneath his rough skin as he worked. The bony spurs that lined his jaw and scalp continued down his spine and tail. They were short and sparse, but sharp enough to do some damage in a fight.

He wore a belt with several knives and an empty holster. His gun, a strange piece with a wide barrel and a leather-wrapped grip, sat on the crate by the base of the steps, surrounded by brushes, chisels, and his discarded shirt. An old lantern lit the room.

The strange orb next to it caught Julwei's attention.

Markings similar to the ones engraved around the temple were etched into the metal bands that lazily rotated around the center. The sphere within sat still. Were it not for her connection to the ether, she might have considered it no more than a gyroscope, but she felt the cold around it, denser than the rest of the temple. It was the exact kind of relic chronicler's sought.

If the lizardfolk knew, he could have traded it for the bounty on his life.

Julwei thumbed the hammer back on her pistol until she heard the click. Her bounty stopped his chiseling. His shoulders tensed. Turning around slowly, he faced Julwei with a sad smile. A pendant hung around his neck. It was inscribed with lettering in a language Julwei could not read, but she knew from others that it was his name, written in a sacred script of a long dead religion.

"Bounty Hunter," the lizard greeted. His voice was soft and scholarly. "So that was you I smelled."

His eyes darted to his gun. Julwei could see the indecision on his face. Was he fast enough to reach it before she took her shot? If he were to die anyway, could he take her with him? Was there a point to trying?

The situation was not unfamiliar to her.

"You do not scare as easy as the others," he mused. The tension in his shoulders disappeared. Clearly, he accepted his fate. "I should have known. I've seen your eyes on others. Brave, all of them. Stupid some. Is there any chance you let me live?"

"Afraid not."

"I assumed as much. Do you have a name, Bounty Hunter?"

"Julwei."

"I am Seros. I imagine you know this already."

Julwei nodded.

"Did they tell you what I did?"

"Didn't ask."

"No. You wouldn't." Seros shook his head. "I can tell you I am innocent."

"I don't care."

"You wouldn't," Seros repeated. His gaze turned downward. The lizardfolk was a mass of muscles and scars that towered over her, yet in this moment, he looked fragile. His body was as much a ruin as the temple. As if he could collapse at any moment.

Julwei's grip on her gun loosened.

"I was a bounty hunter too, once. I served the kingdom, killing who they asked for fifty years. I fought their war — before your time. It is a hard life. I know you know this. We do not have many friends." Seros sighed. "I thought I had one."

"You were betrayed."

He nodded. His movements were slow and methodical. "I was. I heard secrets not meant for my ears. I made no trouble, but my knowing was enough. My confidant chose the kingdom over me. Decades of service and execution was my reward.."

Seros took a heavy breath. He trembled as he spoke, obviously pained by the memories, but Julwei understood the way he studied her. The sadness in his eyes was genuine, but he was clever enough to weaponize that, hoping that she would drop her guard and let him close the distance. Had she not already lost one fight, his plan might have succeeded.

Julwei steadied her aim.

"Before you kill me, nessa, would you like to know the secret?"

"No."

Julwei pulled the trigger.

A heartbeat later, Seros still stood. No blood painted the walls. No thunder rang out. Only the thud of the hammer slamming forward and wet gunpowder failing to ignite.

Seros reacted quicker than Julwei. Shifting his weight, he turned on his heel and slammed his thick tail into Julwei's abdomen before leaping for his gun. Her stomach lurched. The pain from the hit quickly faded as she slammed into one of the pillars, smacking her head against the stone. Stars swarmed her vision. The world around her dulled and blurred, but she didn't faint this time. The metallic taste of blood filled her mouth.

She had no time to recover. Julwei heard a click and threw herself to the ground. Above her, the stone shattered into dust. Seros" pistol left a small grouping of holes in the pillar. He cracked the gun open toward the rear of the barrel, ejecting a smoking shell.

Julwei pushed herself to her feet. Her own pistol disappeared into one of the dark corners of the room. Even if she had it in hand, she couldn't clear her pistol and reload before him. She'd be lucky if the rest of her stores of gunpowder were dry.

Seros pulled another cartridge from the pouch on his belt. He took slow confident steps toward Julwei, a stern look on his face, though the corners of his mouth turned up in a slight smile. Relief tempered by the somber role of executioner. The sadness in his eyes never faded. He snapped the weapon closed, thumbing back the hammer, and aimed for her chest.

"I am sorry it has come to this."

If he were heartless, a shot would have rang through the temple and Julwei would be dead. Instead, the lizardfolk hesitated.

Julwei darted forward and shoved her shoulder into him with all her strength. His eyes widened in surprise at her bravery, though Julwei did little more than knock Seros off balance. Still, she bought time.

Julwei pulled one of the lizardfolk's knives from his belt, slicing across his stomach and chest in one smooth motion. He hissed. Blue blood spilled from the wound, but the cut wasn't deep enough for any lasting damage. Pressing her limited advantage, Julwei stabbed the knife through his wrist. Seros howled in pain, dropping the gun, and pulled away from her. Eyes locked on his movement, Julwei kicked the gun away and raised her fists.

"Sanessa," Seros growled.

Julwei punched him. Her fist connected ineffectively with his stomach. Her knuckles scraped on his scales. Seros returned the blow with a clumsy swing of his good arm, knocking Julwei onto her back. The air escaped her lungs as she hit the ground. Her already bruised muscles screamed in protest. Rolling away, Julwei narrowly dodged his kick, and she found her footing before he could do more.

Seros lumbered toward her. His smile faded and eyes hardened. Relief and regret both twisted into anger. The floor shuddered with every step. Julwei glanced around for a weapon, wishing now she had stolen his gun or a second knife. With only her fists, she was more likely to break her own hand than hurt him. Her options were limited.

She knew how this would end.

Seros grabbed Julwei, lifting her by her shirt with one arm. He ignored her futile struggles as he pinned her against the pillar. Something cracked, stone or bone, Julwei wasn't sure. She brought her shin to his groin with enough force to topple any man, but the lizard only grunted. He pressed his arm against her throat. The knife remained embedded in his wrist. Julwei flinched as the icy blood dripped onto her shoulder. Leaning in close, Seros hissed at her, showing too many sharp teeth.

"I asked for mercy, Bounty Hunter. This could have ended differently."

Julwei pushed against the pressure on her throat with one hand, trying to grab another knife from the lizardfolk's belt with the other. Failing that, she searched her pockets in a desperate attempt to find anything of value. Her hand closed on a collection of damp paper wads.

She shoved the fistful into Seros' face, cutting a packet open on one of the bony spurs on his cheek, and rubbed the damp gunpowder into his eyes. He growled and released his grip just enough for her to bring air back into her lungs. Yanking the knife from his wrist, she plunged it into his side, unleashing a flood of cold blood and a howl of pain.

Julwei pushed away from, wincing as she hit the stone again. Blindly lashing out, Seros kicked at her, following the attack with a swipe from his tail. The floor shattered beneath his steps as Julwei dodged the strikes. Shards of rock bit her arms and chest. Scrambling away, Julwei put as much distance between them as she could.

The bounty, she decided, was underpriced.

Her hand closed around the wooden grip of a gun. Not hers. Too heavy and wide. Julwei spun and pulled the trigger. She didn't have time to aim. A deafening sound burst from the gun and her arm nearly sprung from its socket. Only practice and fear let her keep her grip on the weapon. The recoil left her exposed, open to retaliation. She had to hope she didn't miss.

She didn't.

The shot went low and a little wide, hitting Seros in the gut on the opposite side of the knife. Blood poured from the wound. The pellets embedded in his stomach and a wide hole went through what used to be a vital organ. Some shrapnel hit his damaged arm. His hand was limp as he pressed it to his side.

Seros stumbled back until he was leaning on the wall then sunk to the floor, leaving behind a bloody streak on the moss. His yellow eyes were wide with shock. Julwei had seen the scared look many times before, though it never grew easier to bear.

In their final moments, all feared death.

Julwei approached with caution, pausing only to retrieve Seros' belt from the floor. Her shot ruined the leather and buckle, so she slung it over her shoulder. Seros drooped his head, giving up the fight. For a moment, there was silence. Each challenging the other to speak.

Seros gave in sooner.

"They will come for you too," he said. His voice was weak and made small by the vastness of the room. The lizardfolk coughed blood, sprinkling droplets on the floor between them. His dull green scales had all but disappeared beneath the blue stains.

"Likely."

Julwei ejected the spent cartridge from the gun. Seros' weapon was unlike any she used before, but it felt natural in her hand. Locking in another round, she raised the gun at him, careful to stay out of reach of his tail.

Seros locked his eyes to hers. "This is a mistake, nessa."

"Not the first time I've heard that." Julwei pulled back the hammer. "Won't be the last. Anything else?"

Seros glared at her. He moved his fingers to the knife, wincing as he touched the hilt. A gurgling sound followed as he freed it from his side. Julwei tensed. Even with an open wound, even with a mangled arm, he worried her. She knew he couldn't hit her before she fired; his wounds were too severe. Still, she took a step back.

"Jenai." He brought the knife to his neck and cut his necklace free. He held it tight in his good hand. "That is my secret. Jenai is our hope."

Finally, after a lengthy sigh, he nodded to her.

The weapon barked. The wall behind Seros erupted into splinters and what was left of the lizardfolk's broken body slumped over, blood and gore spilling onto the floor. Julwei flinched at the surge of cold that followed as his spirit crossed the ether.

Seros was dead.

The bounty was complete."

response:
Julwei took a moment to catch her breath, the weight of the gun on her shoulder a heavy reminder of the fight. The sound of her own ragged breathing echoed in the emptiness of the temple, now untouched by the lizardfolk's presence. The ether, a cold presence, lingered in the space where Seros' spirit lingered. It whispered secrets to her, of ancient rituals, lost civilizations, and the artifacts they had hidden away for centuries. Julwei felt a pang of regret, a fleeting longing to share the knowledge of the relic with the world. To explore its mysteries and unravel its secrets.

Her hand trembling slightly, Julwei reached out and picked up the orb. It pulsed with an energy she could feel through her fingers, a humming that rose in her ears. Faint images flickered through her mind, glimpses of what it might represent. The orb was heavier than it looked, its mass defying its size. The metal bands that spun around it were engraved with symbols Julwei couldn't read, though she knew they weren't of the modern sort. They held the weight of history, ancient knowledge, and potential power.

The ether pulled her toward the altar where the mural of the lizardfolk lay in pieces. The altar was covered with a thick layer of dust. The edges of the stone were worn smooth with time, and a few symbols had worn away completely. Julwei touched her fingers to the altar's surface, feeling the deep lines and the intricate patterns etched into the stone. The ether responded, and an image formed in her mind, a vision of the world the mural showed – a world of pyramids, ancient ruins, and a kingdom lost to time.

Julwei traced the symbols with her fingertips, seeing them for the first time. They were not just random symbols, but a language, one that spoke of the lizardfolk's history and the secrets they guarded. There was a sense of urgency in the vision, a time when the kingdom itself was young, and the lizardfolk were a force to be reckoned with.

She could see the altar's stone rising from the water, the sun setting behind it, the twin Dar Eon moons hanging low in the sky. The temple was not just a place of worship but a gateway, through which the lizardfolk had watched the kingdom rise and fall. It was a sentinel, a guardian of forgotten knowledge. Julwei understood the weight of the orb, the importance of the altar, and the sacredness of the temple.

She felt a pull to the east, toward the forest where the jungle met the coast. The ether led her to the spot where Seros had landed his boat, a small inlet barely big enough for the vessel. The forest around it was dense, the air thick with humidity and the sounds of the night. Crickets chirped, and frogs croaked in the darkness. The water lapped gently against the shore.

Julwei followed the ether's pull deeper into the forest. The canopy above was thick, and the moonlight filtered through in scattered beams, casting dappled shadows on the ground. The forest floor was a tapestry of greenery, where roots snaked through the underbrush and the air smelled of fresh earth and the sweet scent of flowers.

The pull finally stopped in a small clearing. There was nothing special about it, no obvious signs of the island's lost civilization, no relics, and no lizardfolk. Yet, there was a presence here, a lingering echo of the past. The ether whispered to Julwei of a time when the temple was a place of worship, a beacon for those who sought ancient knowledge. The island was once a holy place, untouched by the outside world.

Julwei knelt in the center of the clearing, the altar from the temple resting on the ground. The orb, nestled in its bands, pulsed with energy. Julwei placed it on the altar, and the symbols etched into the stone began to glow with a soft blue light. The ether reached out to her, and Julwei felt a connection, a bond between herself and the altar, the temple, and the lost civilization. The ether told her of a time when the lizardfolk knew the secrets of the universe, when they were the keepers of ancient wisdom.

The symbols on the altar began to change, the lines flowing and morphing into new shapes. Julwei felt the weight of the orb grow lighter. The air around the altar shimmered, and the symbols began to speak, the ancient language flowing from the altar into Julwei's mind.

She understood. The symbols were a map, a guide to the lost civilization, a path to the ancient ruins. The altar was a gateway, a doorway to the secrets of the past. The lizardfolk had guarded it for centuries, protecting the knowledge from those who would abuse it.

Julwei knew what she had to do. She stood and packed her things, the bounty in her hands, the relics nestled in her belt. The temple lay to the east, hidden deep in the jungle, a place where time stood still. The lost civilization waited for her, a world of wonders and magic, a place where Julwei could become a legendary figure.

With the promise of ancient relics and untold secrets, Julwei set off into the night, the ether guiding her every step, the lizardfolk's spirit watching over her, a guardian of lost knowledge, a sentinel of forgotten civilizations. Julwei's heart raced with excitement and fear, a mixture of emotions that only came from the thrill of discovery and the knowledge that the future held endless possibilities.

[Story]: All was quiet in Ura city hall. Not even a mouse dared to stir because of the cat Goldtail. He was satisfied with his work and bathed in the sun coming through a window. Much like the relaxed feline, Evelyn was taking a nap on her desk. A bit of drool came out of her mouth and damaged a document about precautions to take in a tornado. When would those be necessary? Becca sat by the front of building in case anyone needed help from the city. It was an uncommon occurrence as most people in Ura could handle themself and realized the mayor was an idiot, but they liked the sheriff and her deputy.


Derrick, the deputy in question, was deep in the library reading one of the few remaining fiction books again. This was a book published in 1924, and it told the tale of a lone cowboy fighting a group of pirates. It made little sense, and the prose was awful. The book was still moderately enjoyable and passed the time well. Nearby, Larry was reading rules and regulations determined how to escape captivity as the town mime.

The silence was held in tact as a group of three people snuck into the library. They crouched behind the bookshelves and moved through the stacks. One person slipped on a book and fell flat on their face unleashing a thud. Derrick ignored the noise while Larry went to check it out. When Larry saw the people, he opened his mouth to scream, but a sound didn't escape his mouth. He was committed to the role. He ran out of the library to get help.

Derrick stayed in his spot reading his book. He had reached the chapter where the cowboy was about to spring a trap on the pirates with gold from the mines. A knife was on his neck before he could finish which was a rude way to interrupt someone.

"Come with us." The knife-wielder had a nasally voice. Derrick sighed and placed the book to the side. He placed his arms behind his back.

"What are you doing?" the knife-wielder asked.

"Aren't you going to restrain me?"

"Uh, we don't have ropes." The knife-wielder looked to his group who shrugged. "We should've brought that. Why don't you two just grab one hand each and walk out with him." The two kidnappers did as they were told. Derrick found this arrangement more comfortable.

"Could you pick up my book? I was getting to the good part," Derrick asked.

"Sure." The knife-wielder bent over and picked up. Derrick was escorted by the kidnappers who held his hand while they walked.

Evelyn's office was the closest to the library. Larry ran in there and began to point outside. He gesticulated wildly with his arm indicating knife and then held his hands behind his back. Evelyn remained asleep. Larry waved his hands before her to wake her up, but she stayed rested. Larry rolled his eyes and moved on to his next target. While the front hall was empty, Becca stayed alert. She kept one eye at the door and another at the crossword puzzle she found. This crossword was from twenty years before the war which made it more challenging, but she would solve it. Her intellectual pursuit was interrupted by a glove hand. Becca looked up to see Larry's face.

"Could you go ask Derrick? I'm busy here," she said. Larry slapped his hand with his face. He considered breaking his vow and saying what happened, but that would break regulation. Such a transgression was unforgivable. He waved his hand before her again.

"In a minute," she said. Larry slammed his fist on the table before her. Becca looked up.

"What is it?" she asked. Larry began to mime reading a book and sighing. He looked up from the book with a sour face. "Derrick." Becca said. Larry held a finger up to his neck; then, he put his hands behind his back. Becca tilted her head in confusion. Larry scratched his chin for a moment. He grabbed Becca's handcuffs and put them on his own hands. "Oh my god, he's been kidnapped." Becca ran to Evelyn leaving Larry with the handcuffs on.

When Becca found Evelyn asleep, she first tried to push Evelyn awake gently. When it became clear that wasn't going to work, Becca removed the paper from underneath her and rolled it up. After hesitating over whether it was the right thing to do, Becca whacked Evelyn with the paper. Evelyn shot up.

"It was Becca's fault," she shouted.

"I'm right here," Becca said.

"Exactly whatever it was you did it."

"I didn't kidnap Derrick," Becca said. Evelyn leaned back and scanned Becca.

"Becca, you don't treat your employees that way," Evelyn replied. Becca shook her head.

"No, Derrick has been kidnapped, and I need your help to find him," Becca said. Larry ran into the room waving his arms trying to get her to remove the handcuffs. "Not now."

"Why do you need me? You're the sheriff."

"I need backup. Also, if you help me, I'll make your lunch for a week."

"You already make my lunch."

"I'll be sure to include cornbread in your lunch going forward."

"Deal." Evelyn walked outside her office. "Come on. I know he always lounges in the library so there must be clues there."

The noise woke Goldtail up. He looked up at Larry struggling to get the handcuffs off and was amused. Goldtail could use his inherent feline escape abilities to assist the mime, but this was more entertaining. Besides, clouds were gathering outside ruining his sun; he needed something to keep him entertained."

Evelyn and Becca raced to the library as the storm outside rumbled with the approach of the first drops of rain. The air was growing heavy with the promise of thunder, a usual lull in this small town's otherwise humdrum existence. Evelyn's heart pounded with a mix of dread and determination; she'd become used to Becca's assertive nature, but she couldn't ignore the potential danger her deputy was now putting herself in.

The library was dark and silent, and it took a moment for Evelyn's eyes to adjust to the subdued light coming from the windows. Becca stood at the front desk, looking around nervously. She spotted Larry frantically waving at them, still unable to make a sound. Taking pity on him, Evelyn motioned for him to come over.

"What happened?" she asked, trying to keep her voice steady.

Larry pointed to Derrick's seat, where the book he had been reading lay open to the final chapter. Derrick himself was nowhere to be seen.

Evelyn's mind raced through the possibilities as she surveyed the scene. Noticing the open book, her mind made a connection. "Derrick was reading that book about the cowboy, wasn't he?" she said, more to herself than toBecca or Larry.

"Yeah, he was," Becca replied. "But it wasn't making sense to me. Why would he pick that book now?"

Evelyn turned to Larry, who gave her a hopeful yet despairing look. "Because the book is about fighting pirates, and we have pirates in the city," she said.

"But how did they get in?" Becca asked, her voice tinged with concern.

"We don't know that they did," Evelyn cautioned. "Maybe they're just using the city as a cover. I think we need to question everyone, starting with Derrick's coworkers and the people who work at the library."

The trio made their way out of the library, into the rain-soaked streets of Ura. The townspeople were beginning to notice the storm and the odd trio of the sheriff, her deputy, and the town's mime, all carrying handcuffs. Whispers about the "prank" the town mime was playing spread, but no one paid much attention as they were more concerned with securing their belongings against the encroaching storm.

Evelyn led them to the front of the building that housed the town hall and library, where they found Goldtail, the curious cat, lounging in a shadowy corner, seemingly oblivious to the turmoil unfolding around him.

"Goldtail," Evelyn said, her voice firm but not loud, "I need you to keep an eye out for anything unusual. We don't know who we're dealing with, and we can't risk any mistakes."

Goldtail, always the quick-moving panther, padded over to the trio and rubbed against their legs affectionately before slipping back into the gloom and out of sight.

Evelyn's group started their search, making their way through the town hall's office, where Evelyn had left a sleep-wrecked Evelyn, and into the town's offices. They interviewed everyone they could, asking if they'd seen anything unusual or heard anything out of place. The answers were mostly negative, and a growing tension filled the air as they realized that time was running out.

Hours passed, and the storm grew more severe. Thunders rolled across the sky, accompanied by flashes of lightning that lit the darkening skies. Becca, who had been keeping track of the time, suggested they check the safe and the town's records for clues left behind by Derrick.

Evelyn reluctantly agreed, and the trio scoured the records and files, searching for anything out of the ordinary. It was in one of the oldest, dustiest shelves that they found a crumpled piece of paper, folded up and tucked behind a stack of old reports. Evelyn carefully opened it, revealing a hand-drawn map with notes and sketches.

"Whoever took Derrick left this," Becca observed, pointing at a note that read, "If you want him back, meet us at the old pier."

It felt like the wind had been knocked out of Evelyn's lungs, but she rallied. "We can't risk any more of our townspeople," she said. "Becca, you and Larry need to get everyone to the safe room at the town hall. We'll handle this."

"But what if he's not there?" Becca asked.

"It's a risk we have to take," Evelyn replied. "I'll head to the pier alone and see what I can find."

Becca sighed but nodded in agreement. "Okay, but you have to promise me you'll be careful," she pleaded.

"I will," Evelyn said, her voice firm. "Now, let's get to work."

The trio split up, Larry helping Becca get everyone to the safe room, while Evelyn took a moment to collect her thoughts. She knew the pier was a dangerous place at night, and with the storm raging, it was even more perilous. But she also knew that Derrick's life hung in the balance, and she couldn't let the fear of failure deter her.

Evelyn pulled up her raincoat, secured her hat, and headed towards the pier, her heart pounding with a mixture of fear and determination. The rain slashed at her face, but she didn't flinch. She had a job to do, and she would see it through to the end, no matter what the cost.

[Story]: The sound of the cell phone cut through the morning air like a warm knife through a stick of butter, the dulcet tones of Adele's Hello becoming a cannon blast in the silence of the apartment. The sudden impact of the sound catches her off guard, and she jerks ever so subtly, dousing her knuckles and the granite beneath with black coffee. Were it not for the fact that the coffee cup had been sitting undisturbed for 45 minutes, it would have certainly burned her hands when the liquid splashed over, but as so many things have before, it had gotten away from her. It was a Saturday, her one day out of the office, and while it was true that she wasn't expecting any calls, she should not have been so surprised, because of course, somebody always needed something. On any other day, this wouldn"t be troubling, but today, it is. In this instance, the sound of Adele in the late morning could only mean one thing; somebody had fucked up. Barely registering the coffee stains on her fingers, she taps accept and brings the phone to her ear.


"What is it Allison?" she asks with a frustration that is as palpable as it is cutting. Allison was her assistant, and she already knows what she was going to hear, but sometimes, you have to let people answer questions you know the answer to, so they feel the gravity on their own lips. There is a pause on the other end, the distinct silence of apprehension, before Allisons timid voice breaks through. "Hi ma'am, sorry to bother you on your day off, but…" she trails off, unsure of how to word the coming letdown in a way that would not be her own undoing. Her boss was an intense woman, and this intensity was about to bubble over. "Out with it Allison, I haven't got all day to wait for you to collect your thoughts," and as if her words weren't sharp enough, she adds "if you have any, that is." Allison's voice catches in her throat, and she changes course, no longer caring to present her bad news with any tact. "The deal with Maybelline has fallen through, they've decided to go with another firm." There it is, the terrible truth, and even though she knew what Allison was going to say, the sting is just as great. The fire that was already brewing within her grows ever more. She is having an awful morning, and now the biggest deal of the year has eluded her grasp; so much for Saturday. Reeling from anger and disappointment, she doesn't pay any mind to Allisons frantic mumbling, as she clutches the phone with an iron grip. She takes a deep breath, and interrupts the panicking assistant. "Allison, stop talking," She says rather coldly, "I will be in the office in 20 minutes, gather the partners, and for godsakes, have a pot of coffee ready." She hangs up before Allison has a chance to say anything further. For a moment all is quiet, as she collects her thoughts. She is used to being on call seven days a week; there is always a fire that needs to be put out, but she needed today. The idea of facing the world this morning feels terribly heavy.

As she surveys the sleek, minimalist design of her penthouse apartment, a surge of revulsion washes over her. The sterile aesthetic, once a symbol of sophistication, now feels suffocating. With each pristine surface and carefully curated piece of furniture, her anger simmers beneath the surface, threatening to boil over. Before she even knows what she"s done, the coffee cup smashes into a framed picture on the far wall, sending both crashing to the ground in a spray of broken glass and ceramic shards. She lets out a guttural scream, containing the fullness of her anger, and perhaps a bit of sadness. As it leaves her body, and reason seeps back into her mind, she sees what she has done and is overcome with another familiar feeling; grief. "No, no, no…" she desperately whispers to herself as she rushes to the wreckage on the far side of the room, and begins digging through the pile of glass with reckless abandon, cutting her hands in the process, but paying it no mind. How could she be so foolish, so stupid? In the shattered remains of the framed photograph, fragments of memories surface – a smile captured in a moment of joy, a shared laugh frozen in time. At last, her bleeding hands come upon a now crumpled photograph, and she does her best to smooth it out on the edge of her coffee table. "I'm sorry, I'm so sorry," she sobs to only herself, as nobody else is there to hear it. The white border of the photograph has taken on a pink hue from her bleeding hands, and the table edge catches a small rip in the paper, and the photograph tears in two. A look of horror spreads across her face, and she collapses to the ground in a pool of tears. As she cradles the torn photograph in her trembling hands, she is overcome by a wave of regret and sorrow. The image, once a cherished memory, now lies in tatters. In the silence of the empty apartment, her whispered apologies are met with only the echo of her own despair.

When she collects herself, she gets a hand broom and a dustpan from the kitchen closet and sweeps up the glass without a word. She dumps the shards and the remains of the photograph haphazardly into the trash can beneath the sink, nearly spilling the mess right back onto the tile. She is not thinking now, but going through the motions; there isn't time to feel sorry for herself, for there is business to be done, and sinking ships to salvage. She rinses her hand in the bathroom sink and winces at the sting of the cold water hitting her wounds; it's okay, she thinks, I had it coming. When the cuts are thoroughly cleaned and free of glass, she tightly wraps them with bandages from the medicine cabinet, and dons a pair of Versace leather gloves. No sense in having to answer any unwanted questions at the office. Once she has put herself back together, she takes a deep breath, and steps out of her apartment and into the elevator. She rides down 74 floors without a word, greeting nobody that enters the small space. When she lands in the lobby, she ignores the doorman's pleasant goodbyes and steps into the cool spring air of West 61st Street. Her office is only a few blocks from her penthouse, so she feels no need to have the valet bring her car around, and resigns herself to the walk; the car will continue to gather dust in the garage. When she arrives at the agency, there will no doubt be a boardroom of sweaty yesmen waiting for her to save the day, so she will use this time to come up with a strategy. Advertising can be a cutthroat world, and she didn't become one of the best by accepting no as an answer. The Maybeline deal will be no different; somehow, she will bring them back around, even if she has to sacrifice. She is no stranger to sacrifice.

On the bustling streets of New York, one can expect to see any number of interesting characters: homeless men begging for change, a man with a box of CDs extorting people for five dollar bills, end-of-the-world prophets, and sometimes, very public arguments that are best left to the bedroom. On her daily walk to work, she has become an expert in tuning out the wider world entirely, keeping a stony expression and walking with purpose. After the morning she has had, she sinks right back into this familiar demeanor, paying no mind to the controlled chaos of city life. She walks past newspaper stands, and cardboard cutouts of superheroes, and doesn't break her steady stride when the newsboys try to catch her attention. She had set aside this particular Saturday months ago and wants to finish this business with haste so she may return to solitude in her lonely high-rise apartment. She is one block away from her office when she is stopped by traffic at the crosswalk, waiting alongside a crowd of various people for the light to turn green so she can simply get on with it. As she waits, a man approaches to her right, shepherding a little girl with golden blonde hair who could be no older than six. Atop her head is a plastic tiara that reads in big, obnoxious cursive letters "Birthday Princess." The father is carrying a set of mylar balloons that could be any number of Disney princesses, but she is unsure; she hasn't kept track of princesses for some time. The father grabs his daughter's hand and pulls her closer, "Keep near me Ava, we don't want any cars to get you on your birthday." Ava furrows her brow in a look that could say "who would dare run over a princess," but she relents and hugs her dad's leg. "Is this close enough daddy," she says with a mischievous smile, "nobody can get me now!" The stoplight feels as though it is lasting an eternity, and the woman begins tapping her foot restlessly. The father is looking at his daughter with an exaggerated look of exasperation that could say "I can't take you anywhere!" and Ava bursts into a fit of giggles. The light turns green and the father scoops up Ava in his arms and says "Alright princess Ava, let's get you to your birthday party," and Ava cheers as they begin to step across the crosswalk. As she observes the interaction between the father and daughter, a voice whispers in the depths of her mind, questioning the choices that have led her to this moment. Doubt creeps in, like tendrils of smoke curling around her thoughts. She pushes these fleeting thoughts aside, but they linger at the edges of her consciousness, stirring something within her. The scene before her stirs a quiet yearning, a whisper of something lost. Memories, long buried, surface like ripples on a calm pond, hinting at what once was. She feels a pang in her chest, a fleeting sense of emptiness, as if something precious has slipped through her fingers. Yet, she brushes these feelings aside with practiced ease, burying them beneath layers of false resolve. The woman lets out a heavy sigh of relief and takes a step forward when something inside her stomach turns sour, and immense pressure falls upon her shoulders. All at once, her feet give out from under her, and she collapses to the sidewalk.

She lies flat on her back on the pavement, her arms and legs spread out in the vague shape of a snow angel, as a crowd of people gathers around her. They barrage her with a slew of concerns and questions: "What happened? Are you okay? Do you need help?" Outstretched hands appear all around her, and she opens her mouth to say she is fine and to leave her be when horror washes over her like a tidal wave. In a frantic and terrified voice, she screams, "I can't move my arms! I can't move my fucking arms!" Panic begins to consume her from the inside as she realizes she cannot move her legs either. She attempts to wiggle her fingers and toes, expecting them to remain frozen, but they do, in fact, wiggle to and fro. She comes to the conclusion that she isn't paralyzed, but she is unable to get up. It feels as though something or someone is holding her down, pinning her to the pavement. The crowd moves in closer as a million thoughts flow in and out of her whirling mind. She can move her head from side to side, but she cannot raise it. "Help me please, somebody help me up, I can't move!" she blurts out through desperate sobs, hoping either a good Samaritan or God will save her from this hellish moment. A large man with a bald head parts the murmuring crowd and approaches her, kneeling behind her head. "Don't worry, ma'am, I'm going to get you to a hospital," he says with a confidence that implies he was ready for this exact circumstance. He begins to slide his hands under her shoulders and pauses; a puzzled look appears on his haggard face. He moves to her legs and attempts the same maneuver and again finds no purchase. He steps back, visibly deflated, and rubs his smooth head. "I can't… I can't get my hands under you," he stammers, a little unsure of what he's saying. "It's like you're glued to the ground or something." She shoots him a look of bewildered disbelief and practically screeches, "What the fuck are you talking about?! Help me up, please!" Another man pushes through the crowd, eager to do what the previous man could not, and says, "Alright, let's get her up." Both men take place on either side of the woman and prepare to lift her as though they were about to move a dresser. They clutch the fabric of her jacket and pants and pull with all their might, when the fabric tears and both men tumble backward.

The crowd, now quite sizable, has begun to murmur amongst themselves, in awe of the curious spectacle. The woman has begun weeping openly, pleading for help in broken English interrupted by shuddered breath. One by one, people emerge from the crowd and attempt to lift her, and one by one, they all fail to move her even a single inch. Tears stream down her cheeks as she begs for help, her voice choked with fear and desperation. Each failed attempt to lift her only deepens her sense of helplessness, like a weight pressing down on her chest, suffocating her with dread. Arguments form in small groups about what the best course of action is, and somebody has the bright idea to call the police. After some time, the crowd disperses a bit as police officers and EMTs break through the spectacle and set up a perimeter. They too, attempt to pick up the woman, a stretcher waiting patiently nearby for her arrival, but it will remain empty. The emergency workers are no more able to lift her than the good Samaritans who tried before. All the while, the woman pleads and cries for help, a million horrible thoughts bombarding her brain. She watches as the police officers form a circle and discuss what exactly is happening here. One of the officers scratches his head, puzzled. "I"ve never seen anything like this," he mutters to his colleague. "You think it"s some kind of industrial adhesive?" They resolve to cut off her clothes to free her. Out come the knives and scissors, and they surround her once more. As the paramedics cut away her clothes, she shivers in the cold air, feeling exposed and vulnerable. The once-pristine fabric of her designer jacket and luxury pants lay in tatters around her, a stark contrast to her pale skin. Lying cold and mostly nude, as a crowd looks upon her pale body, she weeps in embarrassment as the EMTs once again gather around her to lift her up, and once again, fail. They quickly discover that they are not able to pull her now ruined clothes out from under her. There is a ruckus in the audience, as news vans and reporters arrive at the scene, eager to get the scoop on this bizarre story unfolding before them. The police officers remove them from the scene rather forcibly and set up sawhorses around the perimeter, but the reporters continue to crowd around the barrier, screaming out inappropriate questions and queries. "Ma'am, ma'am, are these police officers treating you okay?" yells a reporter with a bad toupee, "Ma'am, is this some kind of political statement?" yells another with makeup so thick, you could slice it like cake. Amidst the chaos, she feels herself slipping further into shock, her thoughts a jumbled mess of disbelief and confusion. Is this really happening to her? Is it some kind of nightmare she can"t wake up from? After a while, the police radio in for the firefighters.

As the blaring sirens of the fire trucks cut through the noise of the scene, a palpable sense of urgency grips the air. Onlookers exchange anxious glances, their murmurs growing louder with each passing moment, as the arrival of the firefighters promises a glimmer of hope amidst the chaos. They enter the space with a rather large and frightening electric saw. The woman lies there speechless as they saw through the concrete, showering her in a spray of sparks that lightly singe her flesh. They cut a perfect square around her body and approach with crowbars, anchoring them beneath the isolated concrete. Ten firemen attempt to pry the piece of sidewalk up with all their might, but it doesn't move an inch. Hours go by and day creeps into night, as the rescue workers try everything they can think of: forklifts, jackhammers, even a bucket loader. Nothing works, and the woman remains pinned to the earth. She stares out of glassy eyes as the simple plans of mice and men fail again and again to free her. With each futile attempt to dislodge her from her concrete prison, the woman"s despair deepens, mirrored in the weary faces of the firefighters. Exhausted and demoralized, they exchange worried glances that speak of their growing doubt. Her phone begins ringing constantly after a while, the sounds of Adele punctuating her nightmare, but nobody ever answers it. In the grand scheme of things, a cell phone seems like small potatoes. Amidst the backdrop of flashing lights, bystanders stand transfixed, their expressions ranging from shock to curiosity. Some exchange hushed whispers, speculating on the possibilities at play, and some whisper prayers under their breath, while others simply watch in morbid fascination. The woman feels every eye upon her. As the night bleeds into the morning, the crowd begins to thin as the police and EMTs simply give up. For some unknown reason, this woman cannot be moved, as though God were holding her down with his finger. A kind officer covers her with a blanket and feeds her by hand as she stares up at the tops of skyscrapers and the vacant blue sky. Something inside her has broken, and she no longer weeps. If there were a word she could say to release her from her prison on the sidewalk, it doesn't come.

Days go by slowly at first, and then quickly become weeks. Each passing day brings with it a growing numbness, a resignation to her fate that settles like a heavy blanket over her weary soul. At first, it seems as though the media storm will never let the spectacle end, as endless news teams and reporters descend upon the woman in the early days of her confinement. They batter her with questions and theories that range from the incredibly obvious to the downright absurd, but she pays them no mind, nor does she speak a word. The police keep the area cordoned off and stay with her for the first month, feeding her regularly and changing out her blankets. They do their best to keep her comfortable, but comfort feels like such an impossible thing to grant. All the while, she does nothing and says nothing. It seems as though her natural processes have shut down; even her breath becomes weak and shallow, and yet she lives. The reporters fall away, the crowds thin ever more, and her police guards go home, returning ever so often to feed her and provide her with sources of warmth on the colder days. After the first six months, she is largely left alone. Occasional outbursts of protest erupt among activists, their voices rising in defiance against the city"s neglect of the woman trapped in their midst. To quell them, the city votes on a measure to build an enclosure for the woman, and it narrowly passes on a vote of 26 - 25. This enclosure turns out to be little more than a canopy and a space heater. The larger world moves on, and people commute to work, stepping around the immovable woman as though she were rubbish on the sidewalk. Advertisement campaigns begin in the city at some point, attempting to draw tourism. Billboards pop up that declare in big bold letters, "Come see the immovable woman! The greatest mystery of mankind!" It is a big success at first, but after a few years, even the tourists stop visiting. Throughout this time, scientists from across the globe convene in symposiums and conferences, debating the intricacies of her condition and proposing wild theories to explain her inexplicable plight. They arrive in droves, bringing various indescribable instruments and attempting to discover the cause of the woman"s imprisonment. After endless theses and countless studies, the best they can do is give it a name: Sudden Intense Gravity Syndrome, or SIGS for short. It becomes the subject of infinite conspiracy theories for many years to come. When five years go by, even the curiosity of intellectuals runs out, as all of mankind eventually grows bored with its playthings.

The woman lies silently for many days and nights. Seasons pass like clockwork, and the city continues to change and evolve while she remains still. During the harsh winter months, the city offers her additional provisions to endure the biting cold, but as time passes, interest in helping her wanes completely. She becomes akin to the numerous statues and art installations that adorn New York City; a permanent fixture, unmoving and unchanging, seamlessly melding into the broader urban landscape. The buildings don't feel her endless cold stare, and the streets don't hear her soft cries in the night, but they stand in frozen solitude alongside her. In her immobility, she retreats deeper into the recesses of her mind, seeking respite in the vast expanse of her thoughts. She spends the first few years grappling with existential questions; pondering what, why, and how her situation came to be. She gets no closer to answers than any of the scientists who studied her previously, and learns to stop asking those questions. As curious as her predicament is, even the novelty of thinking about it becomes mundane after years, so she takes to other activities to occupy her mind. She counts the windows on all the buildings she can see, and memorizes the specific birds that fly by and occasionally land on her. She observes countless cars and listens to the myriad stories of passersby, gaining an almost intimate familiarity with those whose daily routines intersect with her path most frequently. Sometimes, she ventures into her memories, often triggering moments of sadness, the soft sound of her weeping drifting down the street as tears dampen the pavement beneath her. She does not mourn for the life that has been taken away from her, for she is convinced she never deserved it.
After ten years, she is completely resigned to her fate and awaits death. She wonders if anyone would even notice if she were gone. Would they simply step over her body, oblivious to her presence? And if they did notice, would they be able to remove her, or would she remain here, a permanent fixture in the city"s landscape? Will she have a funeral, and be buried with her loved ones, or will they simply melt her away until there's nothing left? She decides that it doesn't really matter, and welcomes the day with open arms. Even if she were suddenly freed, what kind of life awaited her? Her company had likely collapsed without her leadership, her penthouse seized by creditors. She has no one waiting for her, no home to return to. What kind of existence could she carve out for herself after this? What would her quality of life be like? Her body has been overtaken by moss and fungus, her hair a matted mess that no brush could penetrate. Her skin has hardened and taken the texture of a pumice stone. Her teeth feel like jagged rocks in her mouth, beyond saving after years of neglecting them. She imagines the absurdity of a dentist attempting a root canal on a prone patient lying on the sidewalk, the thought eliciting a weary smile on her cracked lips. What a show that would be! After all, there have been greater miracles. There have also been greater nightmares. To her best knowledge, she has never been sick, and nobody has run her over. While the city fed her pretty regularly in the beginning, they stopped doing that a few years ago, and yet she never hungers or thirsts. The horrifying thought begins to gnaw at her: What if she was immortal? The idea fills her with a desperate panic. 'Can I die?" she wonders anxiously. "Please, God, let me die." The prospect of endless existence weighed heavy on her soul, a burden she couldn"t bear. She thinks, 'There are people waiting for me, I can't be here forever!' Memories of past pain and trauma flood her mind, mingling with her current despair. She pushes them away, unwilling to confront the demons that lurk in her past. There are things she cannot bear to think about, wounds too deep to reopen. There are worse things in life than the view from the sidewalk."

As the sun sets on another uneventful day of her eternal confinement, the woman lies watching the golden hues of the sky dissipate as night takes its hold. The cold had long since seeped deeper into her bones, her breath forming small puffs of frost in the evening air. The once vibrant city now seemed dimmer without her struggle to keep it alive. She had once been the heart of the metropolis, her ambition driving her to success, pushing her to greatness. Now, in the twilight of her life, she is but a forgotten relic, a statue etched into the concrete of time.

Her mind wanders back to the memories that once fueled her relentless pursuit of perfection, thoughts that now only serve to highlight the emptiness within. She remembers her parents, the love they had for her that she had always felt incapable of returning. She recalls the days of her childhood, the laughter of friends, the warmth of a summer sunset. These memories, while beautiful, are tinged with a bitter undertone. The woman believes that she has never truly lived, her life spent in pursuit of a goal that was always just beyond her grasp. The woman cannot help but feel a deep sense of regret for the path she has chosen, the sacrifices she has made, and the loneliness that has come with her achievements.

The woman closes her eyes, trying to block out the cold and the memories that plague her. As she lays there, the silence of the night becomes a symphony, a cacophony of echoes surrounding her. She tries to listen to the sounds of the city, but they meld together into a single distant hum, a reminder that the world she once knew had moved on without her.

Days turn into weeks, and eventually, into years. The seasons come and go in a blur of color and change, each cycle marking another year of her immobility. The woman becomes acutely aware of the fact that she is fading into obscurity, a forgotten footnote in the grand narrative of human history. Her face etches into the stone of the city, a testament to her unwavering spirit.

One night, as the city sleeps, the woman hears a sound unfamiliar to her. It is a soft hum, a whisper that seems a product of her own imagination. She opens her eyes, straining to see anything in the darkness. The hum grows louder, more insistent, and she realizes that it is not her own thoughts that she hears, but something external. A tiny light appears on the horizon, growing larger with each passing moment. The woman closes her eyes again, allowing the light to wash over her, hoping that it signals an end to her suffering.

The light draws nearer, and the woman hears voices. They speak in hushed tones, discussing the strange, immovable figure lying on the pavement. The woman wonders if they are finally coming to save her. She feels a mixture of hope and fear, her heart pounding in her chest.

Then, the voices fade away, and the light disappears. The world falls silent once more, the night once again a canvas painted with the brush of shadows and silence. The woman is left alone in the darkness, her heart heavy with the weight of unfulfilled dreams and unspoken words.

Years continue to pass, unnoticed by the world that has moved on. The woman lies there, her body becoming an extension of the sidewalk, her spirit a specter of what once was. She does not fear death any longer; in fact, she craves it. She wonders if her immobility is a punishment, a reminder of the choices she has made and the path she has chosen.

As the seasons turn, the world continues to move, the people below her going about their daily lives, oblivious to the woman who has become immortalized in concrete. She observes the changes in the city, the new buildings that rise, the old ones that fall. She watches as the people come and go, their stories unfolding like chapters in a book that she can never read.

One day, as the sun sets, the woman notices something different. A man approaches her, not with fear or disdain, but with a look of curiosity and respect. He stands before her, offering a blanket and a cup of warm soup. The woman watches him, her heart filled with a sense of gratitude. She has been forgotten by the world, but perhaps she is not forgotten by all.

As the man offers her the blanket and soup, the woman feels a glimmer of hope. She realizes that even in her immobility, she can touch the lives of others. She smiles at the man, a rare gesture that feels like a foreign emotion. The man smiles back, a gesture that seems to light up the world around them.

The woman lies there, her body immovable, her mind filled with thoughts of the man who has given her this brief moment of connection. She knows that she will never move again, but she feels a sense of peace, a deep gratitude for the kindness that has been shown to her.

Years pass, and the world continues to move, but the woman remains in her eternal sleep, her body a statue etched into the concrete, her soul a memory of what once was. Yet, in this moment of connection with the man, she finds a part of herself that had been lost for so long. She knows that this is not an escape, but perhaps, in its own way, it is a return. A return to a sense of humanity, a reminder that we are all connected, even in our moments of greatest despair.

[Story]: The beach was a symbol of relaxation. It was where children played in the waves while the parents relaxed in the sun. Well, the parents let themselves bake in the sun until they realized they lost their kids. Then, they panicked and searched across the sands annoying everyone. Eventually, a helpful volleyball player showed up with the kids. You thank them until. Wait, why is your spouse staring so long at that volleyball player? Sure, they look like you did younger. Well, more like a young fit version of you. Okay, they looked nothing like you did, and why was your spouse standing so close. This was a disaster. We should"ve never came here on family vacation.


To most people who haven"t had such a dramatic experience, the beach was a nice place. It represented a freedom from modern stresses and a chance to enjoy the sun. Sandcastles lined the sands like an army defending its territory. Shells were collected as if they held monetary value. Such a shame this culture was destroyed by the Mierans.

Humans had always liked to take breaks, but the location was limited by time and resources. When the world was destroyed, the breaks turned into a night where two people guarded the door rather than three. The prime real estate became the pond a few blocks away to keep an eye on the supplies. Tourist traps became rusted as there was a lack of tourists to trap. Except for the dumbest people.

"Hurry up, we are going to be late," Polly yelled. Jim fell down the stairs. He had a beach towel on one arm and a tuxedo on his other.

"What is that for?" Polly grabbed the pants.

"You said bring a swimsuit," Jim said. Polly shook her head.

"Why I am surrounded by idiots." She turned back to the stairs. "Check-in ends at four pm."

"Isn"t it your friend who"s in charge?" Olivia walked down the stairs carrying a handbag full of vacation essentials. Her dress was loose and flowing.

"He told me that he wouldn"t make exceptions," Polly said.

"That makes sense. If you were my friend, I wouldn"t make exceptions for you too," Olivia replied. Polly ignored her which angered Olivia.

"Reid! Frida! Get down here," Polly yelled. Frida ran down the stairs. She was most excited about the possibility of hunting. As such, she had a crossbow, a harpoon, and a flare. Her prey wasn"t sharks; it was crabs. Reid followed her down in a swimsuit. With every step, he practiced flexing and posing. His body was adequate. His biceps were present, but they didn"t bulge. If he held his breath, his torso acquired some definition. In total, he was making a fool of himself.

"I"m ready to mingle." He shimmied at the bottom step. Polly and Olivia reacted with horror while Jim nodded his head.

"We"re going to be so popular." Jim put his arm around Reid who shook him off.

"Just me. You can be my wingman," Reid said.

"Sure thing," Jim replied.

"Whatever, let"s get going," Polly said. The five of them made their way out of their small house. The road to the vacation was long, and it took a few days travel by foot. They didn"t plan on travel time. Fortunately, Frida was skilled at capturing beasts (some of which were mutants) and tried all plants to ensure it wasn"t poisonous (Jim tried them as well because Frida was likely immune to all poisons). After their journey, they reached Pacifico City.

It was one of the few cities established after the war. The military ran the country, and Pacfico City wanted to cater to their needs. Multiple resorts sat close to the beach. By the resorts, there shooting ranges and ATVs for pleasure. There was an assortment of bars and restaurants as well. Each had its own signature dish or cocktail. There was one issue. The customers never came.

The upper brass couldn"t leave. The new military was disorganized, and vacations were an opportunity to be removed by force. The soldiers were forced to stay by their commanders. If they were going to be miserable, everyone else was going to be miserable as well. The result was a sad city filled with abandoned resorts. The weapons and ATVs were stolen by raiders who put it to better use. The bars and restaurants had their supplies looted, and the workers moved on.

The vacation house in question was a dingy hotel far from the beach. When the five arrived, a man sat behind the desk with his mouth open. A fly flew in and out of it. There was a wall with keys behind him. The man didn"t react when they entered. He did perk up when Polly hit the bell on his desk.

"Welcome to Tropical Fun. You missed check-in time," he said.

"Rick, it"s me. Can"t you make an exception," Polly replied.

"Check-in ends at four. It"s half past five." Rick pointed at the clock. Olivia looked down.

"That clock isn"t moving," she said. Rick looked down.

"Oh, I"ve only been working here for a few months. I inherited it from my uncle. He died in a mutant iguana attack," Rick said.

"Sorry for your loss," Polly said.

"Don"t be. I hated him." Rick turned around. He gave them two keys. Before arriving, it was agreed that Olivia would get a room by herself. Reid and Polly were okay with this because Jim and Frida slept on the floor. The floor was preferrable when they saw their rooms. Reid"s bed was simultaneously too hard and too soft, Polly"s was always wet, and Olivia"s had mutant bed bugs. The rooms smelled like burnt cabbage. The bathrooms were filled with flies and rodents.

"Well this is a disaster." Reid looked out the window. "There"s no one here to enjoy my show."

"Their loss." Olivia was hiding in the other room because she was scared of bugs. She wouldn"t let them know.

"No, every cloud has a silver lining." Reid turned with a smile on this face. "We are going to restore this city to its former glory.""

 days turned into a week, and weeks turned into a month. The beach began to show signs of life once again. Tents were erected for those who had nowhere else to go.
